column2: In this garden, where care is taken to group plants well for colour, the whites are planted at the lower and more shady end of the group; next come the pale yellows and pale pinks, and these are followed at a little distance by kinds whose flowers are of orange, copper, flame, and scarlet-crimson colourings; this strong-coloured group again softening off at the upper end by strong yellows, and dying away into the woodland by bushes of the common yellow _Azalea pontica_, and its variety with flowers of larger size and deeper colour.
column3: In this garden, where care is taken to group plants well for colour, the whites are planted at the lower and more shady end of the group; next come the pale yellows and pale pinks, and these are followed at a little distance by kinds whose flowers are of orange, copper, flame, and scarlet crimson colourings; this strong coloured group again softening off at the upper end by strong yellows, and dying away into the woodland by bushes of the common yellow underscore Azalea pontica underscore, and its variety with flowers of larger size and deeper colour.

column2: The plantation is long in shape, straggling over a space of about half an acre, the largest and strongest-coloured group being in an open clearing about midway in the length.

column2: The ground between them is covered with a natural growth of the wild Ling (_Calluna_) and Whortleberry, and the small, white-flowered Bed-straw, with the fine-bladed Sheep's-fescue grass, the kind most abundant in heathland. The surrounding ground is copse, of a wild, forest-like character, of birch and small oak.

column2: In the case of small gardens, where there is only room for one bed or clump of peat plants, it would be better to have a group of either one or the other of these plants, rather than spoil the effect by the inharmonious mixture of both.

column2: I always think it desirable to group together flowers that bloom at the same time.
column3: I always think it desirable to group together flowers that bloom at the same time.

column2: It is impossible, and even undesirable, to have a garden in blossom all over, and groups of flower-beauty are all the more enjoyable for being more or less isolated by stretches of intervening greenery.
column3: It is impossible, and even undesirable, to have a garden in blossom all over, and groups of flower beauty are all the more enjoyable for being more or less isolated by stretches of intervening greenery.

column2: As one lovely group for May I recommend Moutan Paeony and _Clematis montana_, the Clematis on a wall low enough to let its wreaths of bloom show near the Paeony.
column3: As one lovely group for May I recommend Moutan Paeony and underscore Clematis montana underscore, the Clematis on a wall low enough to let its wreaths of bloom show near the Paeony.

column2: The old Guelder Rose or Snowball-tree is beautiful anywhere, but I think it best of all on the cold side of a wall.
column3: The old Guelder Rose or Snowball tree is beautiful anywhere, but I think it best of all on the cold side of a wall.

column2: Of course it is perfectly hardy, and a bush of strong, sturdy growth, and has no need of the wall either for support or for shelter; but I am for clothing the garden walls with all the prettiest things they can wear, and no shrub I know makes a better show.
column3: Of course it is perfectly hardy, and a bush of strong, sturdy growth, and has no need of the wall either for support or for shelter; but I am for clothing the garden walls with all the prettiest things they can wear, and no shrub I know makes a better show.

column2: Moreover, as there is necessarily less wood in a flat wall tree than in a round bush, and as the front shoots must be pruned close back, it follows that much more strength is thrown into the remaining wood, and the blooms are much larger.
column3: Moreover, as there is necessarily less wood in a flat wall tree than in a round bush, and as the front shoots must be pruned close back, it follows that much more strength is thrown into the remaining wood, and the blooms are much larger.

column2: I have a north wall eleven feet high, with a Guelder Rose on each side of a doorway, and a _Clematis montana_ that is trained on the top of the whole.
column3: I have a north wall eleven feet high, with a Guelder Rose on each side of a doorway, and a underscore Clematis montana underscore that is trained on the top of the whole.

column2: The two flower at the same time, their growths mingling in friendly fashion, while their unlikeness of habit makes the companionship all the more interesting.
column3: The two flower at the same time, their growths mingling in friendly fashion, while their unlikeness of habit makes the companionship all the more interesting.

column2: The Guelder Rose is a stiff-wooded thing, the character of its main stems being a kind of stark uprightness, though the great white balls hang out with a certain freedom from the newly-grown shoots.
column3: The Guelder Rose is a stiff wooded thing, the character of its main stems being a kind of stark uprightness, though the great white balls hang out with a certain freedom from the newly grown shoots.

column2: The Clematis meets it with an exactly opposite way of growth, swinging down its great swags of many-flowered garland masses into the head of its companion, with here and there a single flowering streamer making a tiny wreath on its own account.
column3: The Clematis meets it with an exactly opposite way of growth, swinging down its great swags of many flowered garland masses into the head of its companion, with here and there a single flowering streamer making a tiny wreath on its own account.

column2: On the southern sides of the same gateway are two large bushes of the Mexican Orange-flower (_Choisya ternata_), loaded with its orange-like bloom.
column3: On the southern sides of the same gateway are two large bushes of the Mexican Orange flower (underscore Choisya ternata underscore), loaded with its orange like bloom.

column2: Buttresses flank the doorway on this side, dying away into the general thickness of the wall above the arch by a kind of roofing of broad flat stones that lay back at an easy pitch.

column2: In mossy hollows at their joints and angles, some tufts of Thrift and of little Rock Pinks have found a home, and show as tenderly-coloured tufts of rather dull pink bloom.

column2: Above all is the same white Clematis, some of its abundant growth having been trained over the south side, so that this one plant plays a somewhat important part in two garden-scenes.

column2: Through the gateway again, beyond the wall northward and partly within its shade, is a portion of ground devoted to Paeonies, in shape a long triangle, whose proportion in length is about thrice its breadth measured at the widest end.
column3: Through the gateway again, beyond the wall northward and partly within its shade, is a portion of ground devoted to Paeonies, in shape a long triangle, whose proportion in length is about thrice its breadth measured at the widest end.

column2: A low cross-wall, five feet high, divides it nearly in half near the Guelder Roses, and it is walled again on the other long side of the triangle by a rough structure of stone and earth, which, in compliment to its appearance, we call the Old Wall, of which I shall have something to say later.

column2: Thus the Paeonies are protected all round, for they like a sheltered place, and the Moutans do best with even a little passing shade at some time of the day.

column2: Moutan is the Chinese name for Tree Paeony.

column2: It is a matter of regret that varieties of the better kinds of Moutans are not generally grown on their own roots, and still more so that the stock in common use should not even be the type Tree Paeony, but one of the herbaceous kinds, so that we have plants of a hard-wooded shrub worked on a thing as soft as a Dahlia root.
